title: 105_hr1835
content: The Act is titled the "Civil Asset Forfeiture Reform Act" and establishes rules for civil forfeiture proceedings. Section 981 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to require written notice in civil forfeiture proceedings within 60 days of seizure or discovery of interested parties, with a provision for extension for good cause. Failure to provide notice may result in voiding the forfeiture unless the agency can show good cause for the omission. The government must provide notice of a seizure of property within 60 days to interested parties. Failure to do so may result in voiding the forfeiture unless there is good cause for the omission. Any person claiming seized property must file a claim within 30 days of final notice publication. The claim must state the claimant's interest in the property, and the government must respond within 90 days. The Attorney General must file a complaint for forfeiture within 90 days of a claim being filed, or return the property. If no complaint is filed, the government must return the property and cannot pursue forfeiture. The court may appoint counsel for a claimant who cannot afford representation. The court may appoint counsel for a claimant based on the nature and value of the property subject to forfeiture, the claimant's standing to contest the forfeiture, and the good faith of the claim. The compensation for representation is equivalent to court-appointed representation and is paid from specific funds. In civil forfeiture suits, the burden of proof is on the US government to prove property is subject to forfeiture. An innocent owner's interest in property cannot be forfeited under any civil forfeiture statute. An innocent owner is one who did not know of the illegal conduct or took reasonable steps to stop it. "In civil forfeiture cases, an innocent owner is defined as a person who acquired a property interest without knowledge of the illegal conduct or government's intent to forfeit the property. The innocent owner can demonstrate their lack of knowledge by taking reasonable steps, such as notifying law enforcement about the illegal activity." "In civil forfeiture cases, a person is not required to take steps that would endanger them. A civil forfeiture statute refers to any federal law allowing property forfeiture. A claimant under subsection (j) can get immediate release of seized property." To request release of seized property, a claimant must prove possession, demonstrate substantial hardship if possession is not returned, and show that the risk of property damage is outweighed by the hardship. The claimant must request possession from the appropriate official. To request release of seized property, a claimant must prove possession and demonstrate substantial hardship if possession is not returned. The claimant must request possession from the appropriate official and if the property is not released within 10 days, the claimant can file a motion in court. The court may order the property to be returned to the claimant if the requirements are met. The court may place conditions on release of seized property to preserve its availability for forfeiture. The district court must decide on a motion within 30 days, with the option to extend the deadline by consent or for good cause. Subsection (j) is redesignated as subsection (l). SEC. 3. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS TO TITLE 28, RULES OF PROCEDURE, AND CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES ACT. The amendment to Section 524(c) of title 28, United States Code allows the use of Assets Forfeiture Fund for attorney fees, court-awarded compensation for representation of claimants, compensation for damages to property, and makes changes to subparagraphs. In Rem Proceedings: Rule C of Supplemental Rules for Admiralty and Maritime Claims amended to extend time from 10 to 30 days. Controlled Substances Act: Section 518 repealed. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS TO REVENUE LAWS. Amends Section 615 of the Tariff Act of 1930 to apply Title 18, United States Code to forfeiture proceedings. Section 981 of Title 18, US Code applies to civil forfeiture procedures for customs law violations. Repeals Section 608 of the Tariff Act of 1930 and amends the time for filing claims under Section 609(a). Additionally, amends Section 613A(a)(3) for the Treasury Asset Forfeiture Fund. Amendment to Section 7325 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding forfeiture of personal property, including the filing of claims and sale procedures in accordance with Section 981 of Title 18, United States Code. Amendment to Section 7325 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the forfeiture of personal property without bond if not claimed within specified time. Amendment to Section 7325 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the forfeiture of personal property without bond if not claimed within specified time. Compensation for damage to seized property is addressed in Section 5. Section 2680(c) of title 28, United States Code is amended to apply provisions of the Tort Claims Act to claims involving negligent destruction, injury, or loss of property in the possession of law enforcement officers. The Attorney General may settle claims not resolved under chapter 171 of title 28 for up to $50,000. The Attorney General can settle claims for damage to privately owned property caused by a Department of Justice officer within the scope of their employment, up to $50,000. Limitations include claims presented more than 1 year after the incident or by a government officer within the scope of their employment. SEC. 6. PREJUDGMENT AND POSTJUDGMENT INTEREST. Section 2465 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for post-judgment interest in cases of property condemnation or forfeiture. The United States will be liable for post-judgment interest as per section 1961 of this title. Pre-judgment interest will not be applicable, except in cases involving currency, negotiable instruments, or proceeds of an interlocutory sale, where the United States will disgorge any interest paid to them from the date of seizure or arrest of the property to the claimant. The United States will disgorge any interest paid to them from the date of seizure or arrest of the property to the claimant, as per section 1961 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 7. APPLICABILITY. The amendments made by this Act apply to claims, suits, and actions filed after the enactment date, with exceptions for burden of proof and judgment entry dates.
